snippet: Electric Guest, a Los Angeles-based band offering crisp, clipped, thoughtful pop, played the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night.
abstract: Jon Pareles reviews performance by pop band Electric Guest at the Bowery Ballroom. Photo (M)8
lead_paragraph: Deep misgivings lurk in the lean, confident, sleekly retro pop songs of Electric Guest, a Los Angeles band that performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night. ''I know I, I won't make it/don't know what to do,'' Asa Taccone sang over the tootling major chords and snappy, handclapping beat of ''Waves'' from the group's debut album, ''Mondo'' (Downtown/Across the Universe). On the album, Electric Guest is the project of Mr. Taccone, its singer and keyboardist; Matthew Compton, its guitarist, bassist and drummer; and their producing and songwriting collaborator in the studio, Brian Burton (a k a Danger Mouse). Only future Electric Guest releases will reveal how much or how little Mr. Burton shaped this album. The music shares quite a bit with other Danger Mouse projects like Broken Bells and Gnarls Barkley: analog-sounding keyboards, quasi-vintage bass and guitar tones, and a fondness for the way 1960s rock and soul were distilled by new wave rock.
